text: Whether <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> affects TMZ sensitivity has never been determined .
Binding proteins for <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and / or <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are likely to affect apoptosis and TMZ sensitivity in GBM cells .
<extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds MEK , and that PMA dissociates this complex for causing apoptosis of T leukemia cells ( Lin et al . , 2011 ) .
Thus , appropriate chemicals , which break apart the WWOX / MEK complex , are expected to cause GBM cell death .
Preliminary studies from our screening of chemicals have selected certain small molecules that induce apoptosis of many types of cancer cells ( Lu et al . , unpublished ) .
Indeed , specific inhibition of MEK by selumetinib enhances TMZ - induced cancer cell death in vivo ( Holt et al . , 2012 ) .
Serum factors can be utilized for blocking cancer growth .

For example , serum complement C1q induces apoptosis of prostate cancer and neuroblastomas cells without participation of downstream proteins in the classical activation pathway ( Hong et al . , 2009 ) .
In this event , ectopic <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is activated for inducing apoptosis .

Failure of ectopic <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in inducing apoptosis of glioma cells possessing wild type <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is unusual ( Chiang et al . , 2012 ) .

In most cases , we have shown that <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functionally interacts with <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and both proteins induce apoptosis in a synergistic manner ( Chang et al . , 2001 , 2003 , 2005a , b , 2007 , 2010 , 2012 ; Su et al . , 2012 ) .

A likely scenario is that <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - binding proteins , which are present in GBMs , may interfere with the apoptotic function of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Functional antagonism among tumor suppressors has never been documented in the literature .

However , it is not surprising to find that many tumor suppressor proteins , e.g . , <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Smad4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> PTEN <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , PP2A , and etc . , are significantly upregulated during the early stage of cancer progression ( Lai et al . , 2005 ; Chang et al . , unpublished ) .
Do these proteins act synergistically in blocking cancer progression but lose control eventually ?
Or , do they counteract each other 's function , thus allowing cancer growth ?

Whether endogenous <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> counteracts with the function of endogenous <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is unknown and remains to be established .
One of the unique characteristics for malignant gliomas is their diffuse infiltration into distant brain tissue .

Signal pathways , involving PI3K , <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> mTOR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , NF-kappaB , and autophagy , are believed to confer these migrating cells resistant to apoptotic death ( Lefranc et al . , 2005 ) .

Glioma cells possess <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a receptor for interacting with brain matrix hyaluronan ( Murai et al . , 2004 ; Yoshida et al . , 2012 ) , and secrete hyaluronidases and metalloproteinases to facilitate their migration ( Delpech et al . , 2002 ; Junker et al . , 2003 ; Hagemann et al . , 2012 ) .
Also , lack of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is expected to enhance cell migration .
For example , loss of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> facilitates migration of ovarian cancer and osteosarcoma cells ( Gourley et al . , 2009 ; Del Mare et al . , 2011 ) .

Ectopic expression of <extra_id_0> TIAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( TGF-beta - induced antiapoptotic factor ) , <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> suppresses anchorage - independent growth and cell migration and causes apoptosis in cancer cells ( Chang et al . , 2012 ) .
We believe that glioma cells , with stem cell-like properties , migrate individually rather than collectively .

This assumption is based upon our observations that mouse <extra_id_0> Wwox <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene knockout cells ( e.g . , embryonic fibroblasts ) migrate individually and aggressively .
In contrast , wild type cells migrate collectively ( Chou et al . , unpublished ) .

While a portion of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is anchored on the cell membrane / cytoskeleton , <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative cells lose recognition by parental <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - positive cells , and this increases the mobility of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative cells to move away from the <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - positive cells .

Conceivably , <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative glioma cells migrate individually and turn away from <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - expressing brain cells to low <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression areas .

Apparently , the migratory behavior of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - negative glioma cells may account for the diffuse invasion into distant brain tissue ( Chou et al . , unpublished ) .

Metabolic alterations have been shown in <extra_id_0> Wwox <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> knockout mice , including postnatal lethality , bone metabolism defects , ataxia , steroidogenesis , and generation of osteosarcomas ( Del Mare et al . , 2011 ; Salah et al . , 2012 ) .

In a Drosophila model , <extra_id_0> Wwox <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is shown to participate in pathways involving aerobic metabolism and oxidative stress for generation of ROS ( O'Keefe et al . , 2011 ) .
Under UV stress , functional <extra_id_0> Wwox <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression induces ROS production in Drosophila .
Cancer cells are known to overly utilize glycolysis for growth advantage - the so-called Warburg ( Moncada et al . , 2012 ) .
Conceivably , <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is likely to override glucose consumption in cancer cells and exerts generation of ROS to curb the cancer cell growth and invasion .

In summary , in this perspective article we have discussed the potential role of tumor suppressors <extra_id_0> p53 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in regulating TMZ sensitivity in GBM cells .

We have shown the role of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in controlling cell migration and metabolic alterations , and discussed the effects of <extra_id_0> WWOX <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deficiency and TMZ resistance in cancer cells .
